channel.title: VoxTalks Economics
channel.description: Learn about groundbreaking new research, commentary and policy ideas from the world's leading economists. Presented by Tim Phillips.
channel.itunes:summary: Learn about groundbreaking new research, commentary and policy ideas from the world's leading economists. Presented by Tim Phillips.
channel.itunes:author: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep49: How did inflation get so high?
item.itunes:title: How did inflation get so high?
item.description: Ricardo Reis tells Tim Phillips why many advanced economies ended up with inflation levels that we haven’t seen for a generation. Did policymakers make mistakes, or do we need to change the entire policy framework?
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep48: Climate and debt
item.itunes:title: Climate and debt
item.description: Mitigating and adapting to climate change is economically rational. But it is also expensive, it’s not clear how the cost should be financed, or which countries or actors assume the burden. The 25th Geneva Report from CEPR investigates these questions. Beatrice Weder di Mauro and Ugo Panizza tell Tim Phillips about the report’s conclusions.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep47: Slowing the spread of the next epidemic
item.itunes:title: Slowing the spread of the next epidemic
item.description: Whether it’s a return of Covid-19 or another epidemic, we now know much more about the best policies to protect economies while limiting the spread of infection from place to place. Flavio Toxvaerd tells Tim Phillips about new research on what will work next time.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep46: How does climate change affect asset prices?
item.itunes:title: How does climate change affect asset prices?
item.description: Heat stress from climate change affects the economy, so does it change the cost of issuing debt or the return on equities? Viral Acharya has investigated how this climate risk is priced, and he tells Tim Phillips how it raises the cost of borrowing most for the places and firms that can least afford it.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep45: How social media influences the news
item.itunes:title: How social media influences the news
item.description: We know that millions of people get their news from social media, but does Twitter influence what traditional news outlets report as well? Julia Cagé tells Tim Phillips about a new study of 2 billion tweets.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep44: Violence against women at work
item.itunes:title: Violence against women at work
item.description: When a man is violent to a woman at work, is the outcome different compared to when a man is the victim? A new study reaches some disturbing conclusions. Adams-Prassl talks to Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep43: The illusion of control
item.itunes:title: The illusion of control
item.description: We need a financial system, but does that mean we must also have regular financial crises? Regulation and risk management attempt to eliminate them, but does the cost and effort simply deliver what Jon Danielsson, in his new book, calls The Illusion of Control? He tells Tim Phillips that systemic risk is higher now than it was in 2008.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep42: Does inequality create growth?
item.itunes:title: Does inequality create growth?
item.description: If we are less equal, is that good or bad news for economic growth? Reto Foellmi reviewed the research, and he has some answers for Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep41: Ghost firms and tax fraud
item.itunes:title: Ghost firms and tax fraud
item.description: The problem of fake firms that issue fake receipts so that clients can claim fraudulent tax deductions is widespread but hard to stop, and it’s costing governments everywhere billions in lost revenues. Dave Donaldson and Dina Pomeranz talk to Tim Phillips about how the tax authority in Ecuador recouped lost revenues.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep40: Our workless future
item.itunes:title: Our workless future
item.description: As intelligent autonomous machines become better at doing all our jobs, will there be enough work and income to go around? If only some of us work, who will that be, and what happens to the rest of us? Anton Korinek talks to Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep39: The political economy of lockdown
item.itunes:title: The political economy of lockdown
item.description: During the Covid-19 pandemic governments had to take unpopular measures to restrict our freedoms, and we had to choose whether we did what we were told. Were governments in countries with free media more likely to act – and were their citizens more likely to comply? Tim Besley and Sacha Dray talk to Tim Phillips about their new research.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep38: Divest or engage?
item.itunes:title: Divest or engage?
item.description: When pension giant ABP faced protests about its fossil fuel investment strategy, did it choose to exert pressure on oil companies or divest from them? Jeff Wurgler and Dirk Schoenmaker talk to Tim Phillips about how the finance sector can accelerate a green transition.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep37: Yellow vests and carbon taxes
item.itunes:title: Yellow vests and carbon taxes
item.description: Opposition to a carbon tax was at the root of the gilets jaunes protests in France. Did the protestors think the tax wouldn’t work, or that it wasn’t fair, or that they would personally lose out? Adrien Fabre talks to Tim Phillips about the link between tax and trust in government.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep36: Distracted donors and political violence
item.itunes:title: Distracted donors and political violence
item.description: When aid donors are distracted by domestic concerns, do aid recipients take advantage to suppress political opposition? Data from Africa suggest that they do, Dominic Rohner tells Tim Phillips. Photo: Alisdare Hickson.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep35: The global real interest rate
item.itunes:title: The global real interest rate
item.description: Global real rates are stuck at a low level, and until recently policy rates everywhere were effectively zero. Can we use historical data to explain why this happened, and to predict whether we will be back at the ZLB when inflation falls? Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas and Ricardo Reis talk to Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep34: Covid-19’s impact on innovation
item.itunes:title: Covid-19’s impact on innovation
item.description: The Covid crisis inspired extraordinary innovation. Carsten Fink and Reinhilde Veugelers are two of the editors of a new ebook from CEPR called Resilience and Ingenuity that examines how countries, organisations and industries were able to innovate. Tim Phillips asks them what worked, what didn’t, and whether we can keep up the pace of new ideas.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep33: Causes and costs of populism
item.itunes:title: Causes and costs of populism
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022: Across Europe and beyond, populist movements have recently flourished. What does history teach us about the economic impact of populism – and is our taste for populists a bug or a feature of democracy? Tim Phillips talks to Moritz Schularick and Massimo Morelli.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep32: Levelling up Europe’s left-behind places
item.itunes:title: Levelling up Europe’s left-behind places
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022: In his resignation speech this week, Boris Johnson said that "we need to keep levelling up, to keep unleashing the potential of every part of the United Kingdom". But are Europe's policies to "level up" left-behind places working? Henry Overman tells Tim Phillips why regional disparities are so persistent.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep31: Closing the European data gap
item.itunes:title: Closing the European data gap
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022: Researchers and policymakers need data, but in Europe they often cannot access the right data at the right time. Filippo di Mauro and Ugo Panizza invite Tim Phillips for coffee to explain how these problems hold back research and decision-making – and suggest what can be done to close the economic data gap.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep30: Curing Covid inflation
item.itunes:title: Curing Covid inflation
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022: Supply chain disruption caused by Covid-19 has fed inflation and hobbled stimulus policies. Sebnem Kalemli Özcan tells Tim Phillips about the only solution to this economic long Covid.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep29: Defusing the carbon bombs
item.itunes:title: Defusing the carbon bombs
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022:  Sanctions against Russia have sent the price of oil and gas rocketing – triggering more, not less, fossil fuel extraction, and some giant projects that have been called “carbon bombs”. Mar Réguant and Rick van der Ploeg tell Tim Phillips that these bombs will explode the climate commitments agreed in Paris in 2015.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep28: Inflation and Europe’s public finances
item.itunes:title: Inflation and Europe’s public finances
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022: What are the consequences of an extended period of above-target inflation for the euro area? Agnès Bénassy-Quéré and Giancarlo Corsetti discuss policy options with Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep27: The Economics of Brexit
item.itunes:title: The Economics of Brexit
item.description: The latest CEPR ebook investigates the impact of Brexit so far on the economies of the UK and EU. Tim Phillips talks to three of the authors: Jonathan Portes, Thomas Sampson and Sarah Hall.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep26: The consequences of war for the EU
item.itunes:title: The consequences of war for the EU
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022: What are the long-term consequences of the conflict in Ukraine for the EU? Lucrezia Reichlin and Philippe Martin discuss the impact of the war on trade, energy security, fiscal policy, and green transition with Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep25: Piketty on equality
item.itunes:title: Piketty on equality
item.description: Recorded live at CEPR Paris Symposium 2022: Thomas Piketty’s short new book promises A brief history of equality. He tells Tim Phillips about why institutions are precarious, why policymakers should consider the consequences for inequality before they intervene – but also why we should be optimistic about the long-term trends in equality.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep24: Male and female voices in economics
item.itunes:title: Male and female voices in economics
item.description: We know women are under-represented in economics. But if male economists are more comfortable expressing a strong opinion, does this increase the perceived imbalance? Sarah Smith tells Tim Phillips about new research into the difference between male and female voices in economics.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep23: The price of war
item.itunes:title: The price of war
item.description: How hard will sanctions on Russia bite? Anna Pestova and Mikhail Mamonov tell Tim Phillips about the depth of the economic hardship that the Russian people will suffer in 2022.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep22: What is the purpose of a finance professor?
item.itunes:title: What is the purpose of a finance professor?
item.description: Alex Edmans asked this question in his keynote at the Financial Management Association Annual Meeting and offered some provocative answers. He tells Tim Phillips about passion, luck, originality, and the value of teaching.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep21: The food crisis has no respect for borders
item.itunes:title: The food crisis has no respect for borders
item.description: This week António Guterres, secretary-general of the UN, warned that the war in Ukraine would tip tens of millions into food insecurity. Guido Porto and Bob Rijkers tell Tim Phillips about who suffers and how much from food price inflation.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep20: What can helicopter money do?
item.itunes:title: What can helicopter money do?
item.description: If you're going to drop lots of money from a helicopter, what will happen to the economy? When would it make a difference, and to who? Helicopter money is increasingly being taken seriously as policy. Ricardo Reis tells Tim Phillips whether helicopter money really can solve our economic problems.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep19: Helping fathers to acknowledge paternity
item.itunes:title: Helping fathers to acknowledge paternity
item.description: If fathers don't acknowledge paternity, it affects both mother and child. Should the state increase financial support for single parents, should we incentivise marriage – or is there another option? Anna Raute tells Tim Phillips that the surprising impact of an unrelated German social policy suggests there may be.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep18: The limits of microfinance
item.itunes:title: The limits of microfinance
item.description: Microfinance has helped millions of the world's poor build better lives. But can it help the world's poorest people, who spend most of their lives growing food to feed their families, to diversify into other jobs? Jack Thiemel tells Tim Phillips about the impact of one of these projects, and what it tells us about the best ways to help the ultra-poor.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep17: Inequality and creative destruction
item.itunes:title: Inequality and creative destruction
item.description: Governments are desperate to create innovation hubs or attract tech companies to kickstart economic growth, but that creates winners and losers. Richard Blundell tells Tim Phillips how policy can balance the impact of innovation on inequality and create policies so that creative destruction and social mobility can go hand-in-hand.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep16: How Fox News inspired vaccine hesitancy
item.itunes:title: How Fox News inspired vaccine hesitancy
item.description: At the height of the Covid-19 pandemic, some cable news hosts cast doubt on the effectiveness of vaccines. Matteo Pinna tells Tim Phillips about his research on the impact of Fox News on vaccination rates.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep15: Forced displacement, then and now
item.itunes:title: Forced displacement, then and now
item.description: Syria, Venezuela, Ukraine: forced migration is constantly in the news, but these events have been happening for hundreds of years. Sascha Becker tells Tim Phillips about new research that is discovering the economic impact of mass displacement in history, both on refugees and on communities – and the lessons we can learn from the past.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep14: Motivated science and green innovation
item.itunes:title: Motivated science and green innovation
item.description: Scientists create innovation. Is this because they are paid to do it, or because they care about the outcome? Tim Besley tells Tim Phillips how motivated science drives down the cost of innovation and may accelerate the green transition.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep13: Will Ukraine's economy survive the war?
item.itunes:title: Will Ukraine's economy survive the war?
item.description: Are the Ukrainian economy and financial system holding up to Russia's bombardment? Yevhenii Skok tells Tim Phillips whether emergency policies have been able to maintain liquidity and financial stability, how much damage has been done to Ukraine's productive capacity, and what a post-war financial rebuild would look like.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep12: Do schools change our religious attitudes?
item.itunes:title: Do schools change our religious attitudes?
item.description: Does compulsory religious education make us more likely to believe as adults, and does it make us more ethical? Ludger Woessmann, Larissa Zierow, and Benjamin Arold explain to Tim Phillips what educational reform in Germany can tell us.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep11: Women's liberation, household revolution
item.itunes:title: Women's liberation, household revolution
item.description: Until the second half of the 19th century, coverture laws granted married men almost unlimited power over the household. Moshe Hazan and David Weiss tell Tim Phillips about how abolition changed the number of children in a family, and how well those children were educated?
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep10: Raising the pressure on Putin
item.itunes:title: Raising the pressure on Putin
item.description: Which economic sanctions against Russia are lawful, which are politically feasible, and which will bite? Luis Garicano - economist and MEP - describes what has been done so far and what more can be done.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep9: The lockdown supply shock
item.itunes:title: The lockdown supply shock
item.description: China's Covid lockdown in early 2020 shocked the business world. How did this surprise disruption affect the firms that rely on imported Chinese products? Isabelle Mejean tells Tim Phillips about the economic impact in France, and which firms were most resilient.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep8: A positive inflation target for the euro area
item.itunes:title: A positive inflation target for the euro area
item.description: Inflation reduces economic welfare by distorting demand. But what is the inflation rate that minimises these distortions? Maybe it's a lot higher than our models assume, Klaus Adam tells Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep7: Anti-LGBT discrimination in transition economies
item.itunes:title: Anti-LGBT discrimination in transition economies
item.description: A recent experiment in Serbia, Turkey and Ukraine attempted to overcome deep-seated prejudice against the LGBT community using information. Ralph De Haas and Cevat Aksoy of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development tell Tim Phillips about which messages cut through, and what impact can they have in the face of religious and state hostility.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep6: A French revolution in state-building
item.itunes:title: A French revolution in state-building
item.description: One of the most remarkable achievements of the French Revolution for ordinary people was the reorganisation of local government. Cédric Chambru, Emeric Henry and Benjamin Marx tell Tim Phillips how local state capitals emerged as a result, and what this tells us about how state capacity develops.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep5: Macro-financial policies in an international financial centre
item.itunes:title: Macro-financial policies in an international financial centre
item.description: Since the GFC the UK has used innovative macroprudential and monetary policy tools to maintain stability. But the UK is an international financial centre, and so does this policy framework create spillovers in other places, and do influences from elsewhere affect stability in the UK? Yes and yes, says Thorsten Beck.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep4: Managing risk in global supply chains
item.itunes:title: Managing risk in global supply chains
item.description: Covid-19 demonstrated that modern global supply chains do not guarantee food in supermarkets or PPE in hospitals. Richard Baldwin tells Tim Phillips how risky these supply chains really are, and what we could do to shore them up.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep3: The other great migration
item.itunes:title: The other great migration
item.description: In the 20th century at least 6 million African Americans migrated from poor southern states to northern cities to escape discrimination and poverty, changing the course of American history. At least as many whites also migrated, taking their ideas with them. Samuel Bazzi tells Tim Phillips that they have also influenced social structures and politics in the US.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep2: AI: software for autocrats?
item.itunes:title: AI: software for autocrats?
item.description: The Chinese government isn't just a world leader in the use of AI for facial recognition, its orders are funding innovation in its domestic industry too. But what's good news for entrepreneurs may be bad news for political protest, Noam Yuchtman tells Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S5 Ep1: The gender gap: Nature or nurture?
item.itunes:title: The gender gap: Nature or nurture?
item.description: Are the differences between what men and women like decided at birth, or do we learn to prefer different things? Klaus Desmet tells Tim Phillips about new research that investigates global patterns in 45,397 Facebook interests.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep51: Europe's asylum lottery
item.itunes:title: Europe's asylum lottery
item.description: Refugees from conflicts in Yemen, Syria, Iraq, and many other countries travel thousands of miles seeking a new life in Europe. But how likely are these refugees to be recognised as asylum seekers, and does it matter in which country they apply? Tim Hatton tells Tim Phillips that, despite efforts to standardise the process of granting asylum, there are still big differences in recognition rates across Europe.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep50: Germany's stalled social mobility
item.itunes:title: Germany's stalled social mobility
item.description: New research uses German census data to track the association between success for a child and the earnings of the parent at a much higher level of detail than was previously possible. Sebastian Findeisen and Paul Schüle tell Tim Phillips about the impact of investment in education that was intended to improve social mobility.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep49: Why natural experiments won the Nobel
item.itunes:title: Why natural experiments won the Nobel
item.description:
Josh Angrist, David Card, and Guido Imbens shared the Nobel in 2021 for their pioneering work on natural experiments that, in the words of the committee, "revolutionised empirical research". Steve Pischke tells Tim Phillips about the history of natural experiments, and the impact of the methods pioneered by this year's Laureates.
© Nobel Prize Outreach 2021 Ill. Niklas Elmehed
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep48: Coming out in America
item.itunes:title: Coming out in America
item.description: Two new papers pinpoint the election of 1992 as a turning point in the attitudes of Americans to same-sex relationships, and ask, what has caused this change? Raquel Fernandez and Sahar Parsa of NYU tell Tim Phillips about the complex relationship between political and social attitudes.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep47: Pensions and fertility in Namibia
item.itunes:title: Pensions and fertility in Namibia
item.description:
Do we have children to provide for us in our old age? Pauline Rossi tells Tim Phillips about the impact on the size of families in Namibia after the government granted a state pension – research that might have important implications for economic development in Africa.

Picture credit: paolafrog@flickr
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep46: Tournaments: Playing to win
item.itunes:title: Tournaments: Playing to win
item.description: Tournaments are increasingly being used in business to solve non-routine problems. Florian Englmaier tells Tim Phillips about new research into what gives these teams the will to win. Do they respond to having a common sense of identity, do they want kudos and status from other people, or are they just looking for a cash prize?
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep45: Creating a resilient society
item.itunes:title: Creating a resilient society
item.description: Repeated environmental and economic crises in recent years are encouraging many people to ask, is this really the best way to run a planet? Markus Brunnermeier tells Tim Phillips how we can do a better job of coping with shocks.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep44: How crises rewire our brains
item.itunes:title: How crises rewire our brains
item.description: When we live through a financial crisis, many of us think differently about money afterwards. Neuroscientists can show that the experience changes the physical structure of our brains, and Ulrike Malmendier tells Tim Phillips how this should also change the way that economists think about preferences for risk.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep43: Pension reform and the incentive to work
item.itunes:title: Pension reform and the incentive to work
item.description: As life expectancy increases, so does the importance of a fair pension system that reflects our contribution but won't leave anyone in poverty. Can we create a progressive pension system that doesn't discourage work? Fabian Kindermann tells Tim Phillips how it could be designed.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep42: Rethinking financial globalisation
item.itunes:title: Rethinking financial globalisation
item.description: Even after their role in the global financial crisis, globalised, minimally regulated financial markets are still regarded as inevitable and, on balance, good for us. Maurice Obstfeld of Berkeley tells Tim Phillips about the short but action-packed history of financial globalisation and asks whether we should be rethinking this aspect of capitalism too.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep41: The robots are reshoring!
item.itunes:title: The robots are reshoring!
item.description: Robots and offshoring are blamed for destroying manufacturing jobs in advanced economies. But could automation also be a way to make domestic manufacturing more competitive? If so, those outsourced jobs may return. Alessandra Bonfiglioli tells Tim Phillips why there may be reasons to welcome our new robot overlords.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep40: Using AI to target aid in Togo
item.itunes:title: Using AI to target aid in Togo
item.description: There is often an urgent need for humanitarian assistance in low-income countries. But how can it be targeted efficiently and quickly? Joshua Blumenstock tells Tim Phillips how, in Togo, a combination of machine learning and mobile phone data dramatically increased the effectiveness of Covid assistance.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep39: Pitching with passion
item.itunes:title: Pitching with passion
item.description: If you want your startup to be funded, everybody knows you have to dial up the energy and enthusiasm when you meet investors to the maximum. But is this really good advice for startups, and is a passionate pitch really a reliable signal for an investor? Song Ma of Yale School of Management used machine learning to evaluate thousands of pitches. He tells Tim Phillips whether passionate entrepreneurs make better startups.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep38: The flight from quality
item.itunes:title: The flight from quality
item.description: In March 2020 we all assumed there would be some reaction to Covid-19 on Wall Street but, when markets did the opposite of what most people expected, the Fed had to step in to stabilise the economy. Anil Kashyap and Kathryn Judge tell Tim Phillips what happened, why, and how to stop it happening again.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep37: Remembering Peter Neary
item.itunes:title: Remembering Peter Neary
item.description: Earlier in 2021 Peter Neary passed away. This special episode pays tribute to his work and examines why Peter was held in such affection by his colleagues. With contributions from Patrick Honohan, Richard Portes, Monika Mrázová, Beata Javorcik, and Abi Adams-Prassl.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S4 Ep36: Share vaccines, save lives
item.itunes:title: Share vaccines, save lives
item.description: How many lives could be saved if rich countries shared their vaccines? Less than 2% of people in low-income countries have received even one dose. Mehdi Benatiya Andaloussi tells Tim Phillips about his calculation of how many lives would be saved by the end of 2021 if vaccines were shared more fairly - and how many have been lost because this hasn't happened so far.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks

item.description: Kaushik Basu's time as World Bank chief economist inspired him to think radically about how to change the way the global economy works. He tells Tim Phillips about why public ownership and profit-sharing may be essential, and what we can still learn from Karl Marx.

item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep29: Coping with Covid in developing economies
item.itunes:title: Coping with Covid in developing economies
item.description:
A new ebook from the CEPR and the International Development Policy Journal discusses the threat to developing and emerging economies from the pandemic, and what we can do about it. Ugo Panizza is one of the editors, and he joins Tim Phillips to discuss capital flight, conflict, and what advanced economies and can do to help.
Download Covid in Developing Economies - it's free.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep28: Who gets exposed to Covid-19?
item.itunes:title: Who gets exposed to Covid-19?
item.description:
Different countries and cities have different rates of Covid exposure, but what can explain the difference in incidence between neighbourhoods? New York residents Milena Almagro and Angelo Orane-Hutchinson tell Tim Phillips what made the difference in their city.

Read their research in Covid Economics 13.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep27: The Great Reversal
item.itunes:title: The Great Reversal
item.description: Thomas Philippon's new book argues that in the last 20 years the US has “given up” on free markets. As a result, he tells Tim Phillips, American families are each $5,000 a year poorer.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep26: Structural transformation and economic growth
item.itunes:title: Structural transformation and economic growth
item.description:
This week the CEPR launches a new research programme called STEG - Structural Transformation and Economic Growth. Ahead of the kick-off workshop on June 4 and 5, Joe Kaboski and Doug Gollin tell Tim Phillips what STEG hopes to achieve, and Rachel Glennerster explains why DFID is funding it.
Register for the workshop or discover STEG here.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep25: Time for beds
item.itunes:title: Time for beds
item.description:
The mortality statistics of the Covid-19 outbreak suggest that your country's medical infrastructure has a big influence on how likely you are to survive. Nathan Sussman has examined the data and tells Tim Phillips why all countries should be urgently investing in their health services.
Read "Time for Beds" in issue 11 of Covid Economics.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep24: Tech industry mergers
item.itunes:title: Tech industry mergers
item.description: Should competition authorities intervene more often in tech mergers? Be careful, Luis Cabral tells Tim Phillips: they risk stifling innovation if they do.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep23: Helicopter money
item.itunes:title: Helicopter money
item.description:
In every crisis, economists will tell us that it is time for helicopter money, and Covid-19 is no different. But the helicopters never seem to take off. Donato Maschiandaro tells Tim Phillips why not.
Read about helicopter money in Issue 7 of Covid Economics.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep22: The Swedish solution to Covid-19
item.itunes:title: The Swedish solution to Covid-19
item.description:
Do we close our public spaces to protect our communities from Covid-19, or keep them open, as in Sweden? Dirk Krueger tells Tim Phillips that informing the public and then trusting individuals to make good choices might deliver a decline in infections, while minimising the Covid recession.

Download Covid Economics 5, including Dirk's paper.
Picture: Creative Commons/Vogler
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep21: The myth of British inventive genius
item.itunes:title: The myth of British inventive genius
item.description:
On the 75 anniversary of the VE Day, David Edgerton tells Tim Phillips that Britain's belief in its go-it-alone scientific and inventive genius is “deluded”, and has stunted the nation's postwar growth.
Download The Economics of the Second World War Seventy-Five Years On, featuring David's chapter.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep20: Do the rich get more coronavirus tests?
item.itunes:title: Do the rich get more coronavirus tests?
item.description: Last month the media accused New York's wealthy residents of jumping the queue for Covid-19 testing. Stephanie Schmitt-Grohé, a New York resident herself, ran the numbers. She tells Tim Phillips what she discovered.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep19: We need a Covid-19 debt standstill
item.itunes:title: We need a Covid-19 debt standstill
item.description:
In a new paper called Born out of necessity, a group of economists and  lawyers propose a way for developing and emerging countries to temporarily redirect debt repayments to fund Covid-19 relief. Ugo Panizza and Mitu Gulati tell Tim Phillips how it would work.

Read about this controversial idea at VoxEU.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep18: John Maynard Keynes's art portfolio
item.itunes:title: John Maynard Keynes's art portfolio
item.description: Keynes amassed an extensive collection of fine art during his lifetime. David Chambers tells Tim Phillips what the financial returns on his investment have been, and the insight this gives us into how to value an art portfolio as an asset.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep17: Lessons from the Ebola crisis on dealing with Covid-19
item.itunes:title: Lessons from the Ebola crisis on dealing with Covid-19
item.description: The 2014 Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone affected an area which included a pioneering experiment in community healthcare. Oeindrila Dube tells Tim Phillips about the lifesaving impact of this experiment - and two important lessons we can learn that may help to contain the spread of Covid-19 in Africa.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep16: Modelling the economic consequences of Covid-19
item.itunes:title: Modelling the economic consequences of Covid-19
item.description:
When Covid-19 wasn't even on the radar of most policymakers, Warwick McKibbin of ANU used his experience from previous pandemics to create seven scenarios for its impact. All implied a major shock to the global economy. Tim Phillips asks him how his model was able to capture the nature of Covid-19, and which policymakers listened to the warning.

Read about McKibbin's scenarios in Chapter 3 of Economics in the Time of Covid-19.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep15: How much do governments lend to each other in a crisis?
item.itunes:title: How much do governments lend to each other in a crisis?
item.description:
In international crises, disasters and wars, private lenders disappear. But governments have stepped in and lent far more to each other than we previously thought. Christoph Trebesch tells Tim Phillips that new data on  200 years of official lending may contain unexpected good news for countries crippled by Covid-19.

Read 'Coping with disasters: Lessons from two centuries of international response' at VoxEU
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep14: The coronavirus shock to financial stability
item.itunes:title: The coronavirus shock to financial stability
item.description: Enrico Perotti tells Tim Phillips that while regulatory reform means that banks are unlikely to be at risk, the same is not true for the shadow banking sector. Does this threaten financial stability, and what should policymakers do about it?
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep13: A Covid credit line for Europe
item.itunes:title: A Covid credit line for Europe
item.description:
How can euro area countries work together to protect their economies? A diverse group of economists has suggested the creation of an emergency Covid credit line. Beatrice Weder di Mauro tells Tim Phillips how it would work.

Read about the Covid credit line on VoxEU
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep12: Singapore's response to Covid-19
item.itunes:title: Singapore's response to Covid-19
item.description:
In a VoxTalks special, Danny Quah tells Tim Phillips how Singapore defended itself against the health and economic impact of Covid-19, and what other countries can learn from its actions.

Download the VoxEU book Mitigating the Covid Economic Crisis.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep11: The polarization of reality
item.itunes:title: The polarization of reality
item.description: We think about political polarization as a disagreement about policies. But what if the voters can't even agree on the facts? Stefanie Stantcheva tells Tim Phillips about new research that has profound implications for democracy.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep10: Economics in the time of Covid-19
item.itunes:title: Economics in the time of Covid-19
item.description:
How big are Covid-19's economic consequences? That's the theme of a new VoxEU book with contributions from many of the world's most experienced policymakers with expertise in this area. Beatrice Weder di Mauro and Richard Baldwin, the book's editors, give Tim Phillips the (mostly) bad news.

Download the book: it's free.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep9: Women in Economics
item.itunes:title: Women in Economics
item.description:
Women are under-represented in economics, and the situation is not improving. Economists Shelly Lundberg, Donna Ginther, Jenna Stearns and Erin Hengel talk to Tim Phillips about VoxEU's new book on the subject that examines the barriers that women face in the profession, and also suggests ways to support the next generation of female economists.

Download the book here, it's free.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep8: Digital market merger policy
item.itunes:title: Digital market merger policy
item.description: In the last decade, global digital giants have snapped up hundreds of smaller, innovative companies. Should competition authorities have intervened more often? Tomaso Duso tells Tim Phillips about new research that suggests they should.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep7: The history of immigration quotas
item.itunes:title: The history of immigration quotas
item.description: A century ago, American nativists succeeded in establishing immigration quotas to drive up the wages of US workers. What happened next? Not what you might think, Leah Boustan tells Tim Phillips.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep6: Education creates peace
item.itunes:title: Education creates peace
item.description: New research shows how a school-building programme in Indonesia successfully reduced conflict. Dominic Rohner tells Tim Phillips about this unanticipated peace dividend, and how the CEPR's research and policy network on conflict reduction will help policymakers.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep5: Central banks and regional inequality
item.itunes:title: Central banks and regional inequality
item.description: Is regional inequality a problem that central banks should worry about? Andy Haldane of the Bank of England tells Tim Phillips why he thanks the answer is yes: but why we also need to think about what, and how, we measure.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep4: The origins of tech clusters
item.itunes:title: The origins of tech clusters
item.description: Why are cities so keen to create their own technology clusters, and why is it so difficult? Bill Kerr of Harvard Business School tells Tim Phillips what economists know (and don't know) about where tech clusters come from.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep3: Betting on the Lord
item.itunes:title: Betting on the Lord
item.description: An experiment in Haiti shows that people take more risks in the presence of religious images, even if there is less chance they will win. Emmanuelle Auriol tells Tim Phillips about the challenges that belief in a higher power presents for economic development.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep2: Regenerating the cities that were left behind
item.itunes:title: Regenerating the cities that were left behind
item.description: When the industries that have sustained our cities decline, how can we regenerate urban areas? At the SUERF conference in Amsterdam, Tony Venables and Charles Goodhart tell Tim Phillips that redevelopment policies may have made regional inequality and social conflict worse.

item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S3 Ep1: Will there be a post-Brexit financial services deal?
item.itunes:title: Will there be a post-Brexit financial services deal?
item.description: In 2020, the UK and the EU will try to strike a post-Brexit deal in financial services. At the SUERF conference in Amsterdam, David Miles and Iain Begg explain to Tim Phillips what's at stake in the negotiations, and who would suffer most if there's no deal.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep52: Has the randomista revolution gone too far?
item.itunes:title: Has the randomista revolution gone too far?
item.description:
This year's Nobel prize celebrated the work of the economists who popularised randomised controlled trials, “for their experimental approach to alleviating global poverty”. But is it possible to have too much of a good thing? Tim Phillips investigates.
Picture © Nobel Media 2019. Illustration: Niklas Elmehed.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep51: Burying bad news
item.itunes:title: Burying bad news
item.description: New research demonstrates what we all suspected: for decades, politicians have routinely used busy news days to bury unpopular announcements. Ruben Durante educates Tim Phillips in the politics of distraction.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep50: Helping parents to read with their children
item.itunes:title: Helping parents to read with their children
item.description: Language skills for preschoolers help them achieve more when they get to school, but some parents are better than others at helping their kids to develop these skills. Denis Fougère and Carlo Barone tell Tim Phillips about a successful experiment in Paris to help less-educated parents spend time reading with their children.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep49: Wealth taxes
item.itunes:title: Wealth taxes
item.description: Few countries tax their citizens' wealth annually, but Switzerland is one of them. Marius Brülhart tells Tim Phillips about a natural experiment in Switzerland's cantons that teaches us about how people would respond if more countries decided to tax wealth instead of income.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep48: How the mobile internet changed politics
item.itunes:title: How the mobile internet changed politics
item.description: The mobile internet, promises to give us access to information anywhere, 24 hours a day. So how has it influenced trust in governments, politics, and politicians? Sergei Guriev tells Tim Phillips about how, all over the world, 3G has reduced trust in government and aided the rise of populism.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep47: Can the stock market help save the planet?
item.itunes:title: Can the stock market help save the planet?
item.description:
We think about climate policies as moderating or interceding in markets. 
But a new paper implies that when stock markets play a bigger part in the economy, polluting industries become cleaner. Tim Phillips asks Ralph De Haas of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development whether we already have a green finance initiative under our noses.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep46: The Great Expectations of the middle class
item.itunes:title: The Great Expectations of the middle class
item.description:
When there's a financial crisis, policymakers and politicians increasingly kowtow to the demands of an influential group: the global middle class. Jeffrey Chwieroth and Andrew Walter tell Tim Phillips how their Great Expectations are destabilising the world economy.

Read about Great Expectations at VoxEU.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep45: How to improve consumer credit ratings
item.itunes:title: How to improve consumer credit ratings
item.description: Doing a good job of deciding who can borrow is fundamental for the global economy. Stefania Albanesi tells Tim Phillips that current consumer credit ratings do a poor job at predicting which of us will default, and explains how she has used machine learning to improve them.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep44: Let's stay together
item.itunes:title: Let's stay together
item.description: When the law changed to allow same-sex partners to get married, did the symbolism of marriage have any effect on the stability of relationships? Shuai Chen tells Tim Phillips about a surprising result from The Netherlands.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep43: The cost of dying
item.itunes:title: The cost of dying
item.description:
How much is spent on end-of-life care, and who foots the bill? Eric French of UCL tells Tim Phillips about the total cost of the last year of our lives, and how different countries have very different ideas of who should pay it.

Read about the research at VoxEU.org, and download the VoxEU book about the economics of ageing.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep42: Increasing diversity in economics
item.itunes:title: Increasing diversity in economics
item.description:
The Royal Economic Society has launched Discover Economics, an ambitious three-year campaign to attract more women, minority students and students from state schools to study the subject. Sarah Smith and Arun Advani, co-chairs of the campaign, plus Rachel Griffith, RES president, tell Tim Phillips about how they plan to make this happen.

Read about Discover Economics at VoxEU.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep41: The economics of an ageing population
item.itunes:title: The economics of an ageing population
item.description: We are living longer, and that affects every part of our economic future. David Bloom is the editor of a new VoxEU book on what he calls "the what, the so what, and the now what" of ageing. He tells Tim Phillips about some of the policy choices our societies will have to make in the near future.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep40: A new story of London's economic development
item.itunes:title: A new story of London's economic development
item.description: Economists date the growth of London's financial system, and its impact on the British economy, from the end of the 17th century. Nathan Sussman tells Tim Phillips how how he discovered contemporary records that tell a different story.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep39: Lessons from the Irish banking crisis
item.itunes:title: Lessons from the Irish banking crisis
item.description:
Patrick Honohan took over as governor of the Central Bank of Ireland in 2009 with the economy in meltdown, and steered it through its deepest crisis. His new book re-examines what happened, and lessons for future crises. Tim Phillips talks to Patrick and the FT's Martin Sandbu about what policymakers and central bankers can learn from Ireland's ordeal.

Read about Patrick's book at VoxEU.org.

item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep38: The death of banks?
item.itunes:title: The death of banks?
item.description:
On 24 September the CEPR launches the latest Geneva Report on the world economy, called Banking disrupted? Financial intermediation in an era of transformational technology. Tim Phillips asks Tara Rice and Kathryn Petralia, two of the authors, whether fintechs and cryptocurrencies signal the beginning of the end for banks.

Download the report, or read about it at VoxEU.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep37: Does foreign investment create green growth?
item.itunes:title: Does foreign investment create green growth?
item.description:
Economists argue whether foreign direct investment in developing economies exports pollution or generates green growth. Beata Javorcik talks to Tim Phillips about a surprising conclusion from factory-level research.

Read about the research at VoxEU.

item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep36: The economic history of World War 2
item.itunes:title: The economic history of World War 2
item.description:
Starting on the 80th anniversary of the outbreak of the second world war, VoxEU is publishing a series of articles about the economics of the war. Tim Phillips talks to some of the authors about their research.

Read more about the project at VoxEU.
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep35: Africa's lands of opportunity
item.itunes:title: Africa's lands of opportunity
item.description: On average, if you are born in Africa today you have much better chances to succeed than your parents or grandparents. item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep34: Could a $15 minimum wage save lives?
item.itunes:title: Could a $15 minimum wage save lives?
item.description: The US has an epidemic of "deaths of despair". Michael Reich tells Tim Phillips that new research implies that a $15 minimum wage doesn't just cut poverty, it also saves lives. But is Congress listening?
item.itunes:author: VoxTalks
item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.title: S2 Ep33: Investing in Brexit
item.itunes:title: Investing in Brexit
item.description: As Brexit nears (again), are British firms choosing to invest in the UK or in other European markets? Are European firms investing in the UK to preserve access to its markets? item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.itunes:title: Social media polarization
item.description: When does social media polarize opinion, and when does it bring us closer together? Yves Zenou tells Tim Phillips about a new economic model that shows us how affinity can become division, and why the trolls often win.

item.dc:creator: VoxTalks

item.itunes:title: Learning about ourselves
item.description: Despite all the evidence to the contrary we continue to overestimate how much work we will do tomorrow, or how often we will go to the gym. Why? Peter Schwardmann tells Tim Phillips that we do learn from experience about ourselves - in the right circumstances.

item.itunes:title: France's broken social elevator
item.description: France has surprisingly low social mobility. OECD chief economist Laurence Boone tells Tim Phillips why this is the case, how the problem fuels the gilets jaunes protests, and what can be done about it.

item.itunes:title: The true cost of emissions cheating

item.itunes:title: The benefits of starting school early
item.description:
Children in different countries start school at very different ages. Thomas Cornelissen tells Tim Phillips about new research that suggests an early start may help their development.

item.itunes:title: Italy is a very sick patient
item.description: Are Italy's populist policies of miniBOTs and flat taxes the right medicine for its economic sickness? Fabio Ghironi tells Tim Phillips that, if Italy doesn't attempt fundamental structural reforms, it may be on the path to Eurexit.

item.itunes:title: How the G20 can save world trade
item.description:
As the G20 gather in Japan, Tim Phillips talks to Simon Evenett, one of the authors of the Global Trade Alert, on how the ministers can halt the "free for all" on protectionism.

item.itunes:title: The threat to global prosperity
item.description:
A new book from the CEPR argues that the current trade war is a long-term danger to all economies, not just those of the US and China. Editor Meredith Crowley of the University of Cambridge and two of the authors tell Tim Phillips why prospects for the world economy are 'grim'.

item.itunes:title: What would Ricardo do?
item.description:
David Ricardo was the first economist to think rigorously about international trade, and his theory of comparative advantage has stood the test of time. So why do so many politicians ignore it? And what would he do about Brexit? Peter Neary of the University of Oxford talks to Tim Phillips.

item.title: S2 Ep23: The future of the welfare state
item.itunes:title: The future of the welfare state
item.description:
This week UN special rapporteur claimed the UK's social safety net has been "replaced with a harsh and uncaring ethos". Dame Minouche Shafik, director of the LSE, talks to Tim Phillips about whether our welfare states can survive in their current form, and what might replace them.

item.itunes:title: The Yrjo Jahnsson award

item.itunes:title: The cost of kids

Women earn less than men after they start a family. Can better policies close the gap? Camille Landais of LSE tells Tim Phillips about new research comparing six countries.

item.itunes:title: Managing the secret state
item.description:
Did the KGB manage its informers using the iron fist or the invisible hand? Mark Harrison tells Tim Phillips how the state motivated and disciplined its secret workforce.

item.itunes:title: The end of the WTO?

item.itunes:title: The lost ones

item.title: S1 Ep15: The missing profits of nations
item.itunes:title: The missing profits of nations
item.description:
Every year multinational companies reduce their tax bills by about $200 billion simply by shifting profits, legally, to tax havens. Governments criticise tax loopholes and promise to close them. But at the same time they also use them to attract these paper profits to their jurisdiction. item.description:

[Read about his research on VoxEU](https://voxeu.org/article/decline-northern-england-1780-2018).
